title: Crossing the Jordan
shortSummary: Joshua 4 recounts the miraculous crossing of the Jordan River by the Israelites as they enter the Promised Land. God commands Joshua to set up twelve stones as a memorial to remind future generations of His power and faithfulness. This chapter highlights God's continued guidance and the importance of remembering His mighty works.
timeline: c. 1406 BC - Israel enters the Promised Land after 40 years in the wilderness

keyCharacters.name: Joshua
keyCharacters.description: The leader of Israel who succeeds Moses and leads the people across the Jordan River into Canaan.

keyCharacters.name: The Twelve Men
keyCharacters.description: One man chosen from each tribe of Israel to carry twelve stones from the Jordan as a memorial.

keyCharacters.name: The Priests
keyCharacters.description: Bearers of the Ark of the Covenant who stand in the Jordan River, causing the waters to stop flowing.

definitions.definition: The sacred chest containing the tablets of the Ten Commandments, symbolizing God's presence among Israel.
Twelve stones taken from the Jordan River to serve as a lasting reminder of God's miraculous deliverance.
The river the Israelites crossed miraculously to enter the Promised Land, symbolizing transition and God's power.
A phrase meaning the people had completely crossed the river, emphasizing the finished act of obedience.

outline.heading: God's Command to Set Up Memorial Stones
outline.description: After the people cross the Jordan, God instructs Joshua to have twelve men take stones from the riverbed to create a memorial. This act is intended to teach future generations about God's miraculous intervention.

outline.heading: The Israelites Obey and Take the Stones
outline.description: The twelve men carry the stones from the river and Joshua sets them up in the place where the priests stood, establishing a permanent witness to God's faithfulness.

outline.heading: The Priests Stand Firm and the Waters Stop
outline.description: The priests carrying the Ark stand in the Jordan until all the people have crossed, and the waters cease flowing, demonstrating God's power and presence.

outline.heading: The Crossing of the Armed Tribes
outline.description: The tribes of Reuben, Gad, and half of Manasseh cross armed, fulfilling Moses' earlier command and preparing for conquest.

outline.heading: Joshua's Leadership Magnified
outline.description: God magnifies Joshua's leadership in the eyes of Israel, causing the people to respect him as they did Moses.

outline.heading: The Waters Return and the People Encamp at Gilgal
outline.description: Once the priests step out, the Jordan's waters return to normal. The people camp at Gilgal where the twelve stones are set up as a memorial, and Joshua explains their significance to ensure future generations remember God's mighty works.

application: Remember and recount God's faithfulness in your life to encourage future generations in the faith.
Obey God's commands promptly and trust His guidance even when facing new challenges.
Recognize and honor godly leadership as God establishes and magnifies those He appoints.
Set spiritual reminders in your life to keep your focus on God's power and provision.

keyVerses.text: Then ye shall answer them, That the waters of Jordan were cut off before the ark of the covenant of the LORD; when it passed over Jordan, the waters of Jordan were cut off: and these stones shall be for a memorial unto the children of Israel for ever.
keyVerses.significance: This verse explains the purpose of the memorial stones as a lasting testimony to God's miraculous deliverance.

keyVerses.text: On that day the LORD magnified Joshua in the sight of all Israel; and they feared him, as they feared Moses, all the days of his life.
keyVerses.significance: God's endorsement of Joshua's leadership reassures Israel of His continued guidance after Moses.

keyVerses.text: For the LORD your God dried up the waters of Jordan from before you, until ye were passed over, as the LORD your God did to the Red sea, which he dried up from before us, until we were gone over:
keyVerses.significance: This verse connects the Jordan crossing to the Red Sea event, emphasizing God's consistent power to save His people.
